text: Is it valid to distribute julia binary releases to PyPi or npm? I just got some idea of platform-independent version manager for julia.

elements.text: Is it valid to distribute julia binary releases to PyPi or npm? I just got some idea of platform-independent version manager for julia.

text:
"platform-independent version manager for julia" you mean like <https://asdf-vm.com/#/>?
And I don't think it's accepted to distribute non-Python-related packages via PyPi.

elements.text: "platform-independent version manager for julia" you mean like

?
And I don't think it's accepted to distribute non-Python-related packages via PyPi.

text:
It is my first time to know `asdf` but it looks REALLY GOOD.

>  And I don't think it's accepted to distribute non-Python-related packages via PyPi.
It seems okay for us to upload julia to PyPI under the correct license: <https://pypi.org/policy/terms-of-use/>

Besides, many binary toolchains like GCC have their PyPI distribution, hence I don't think there is a restriction from PyPI side.

attachments.title: Terms of use
attachments.text: The Python Package Index (PyPI) is a repository of software for the Python programming language.

elements.text: It is my first time to know
And I don't think it's accepted to distribute non-Python-related packages via PyPi.
It seems okay for us to upload julia to PyPI under the correct license:
Besides, many binary toolchains like GCC have their PyPI distribution, hence I don't think there is a restriction from PyPI side.

text:
"Acceptable Content is restricted to Python packages and related information."
That's right there in the Terms of Use you linked to. So no, I don't think it's acceptable to distribute Julia via PyPi, unless it's for a Python package that requires a Julia interpreter. In the same way, if toolchains like GCC do have PyPi distributions, it's either to facilitate compilation of binaries needed for Python packages, or it's in conflict with the Terms of Use and those packages should be removed.
